Play details
Frier Bacon, and Frier Bongay. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1594. Date first performed: 1589-1590.

Lacey Warren Ermsby Raphe Edward Bacon Miles Burden Clement Mason Hostesse Thomas Margret Ione Richard Henry Castile Elinor Emperor Bungay Constable Vandermast Hercules Lambert Serlby Keeper Post Head First Scholar Second Scholar Friend Devil

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

body.stage: THE HONOVRABLE Historie of Frier Bacon
Enter, Edward the first malcontented with Lacy earle of Lincolne, Iohn Warren earle of Sussex, and Ermsbie gentleman: Ralph Simnell the kings foole.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: WHY looks my lord like to a troubled sky,
When heavens bright shine, is shadowed with a fog:
A-late we ran the deer and through the Lands
Stripped with our nags the lofty frolic bucks,
That scudded fore the teasers like the wind,
Never was the Deer of merry Fresingfield,
So lustily pulled down by jolly mates,
Nor shard the Farmers such fat venison,
So frankly dealt this hundred years before:
Nor have I seen my lord more frolic in the chase,
And now changed to a melancholy dump.

sp.speaker: Warren.
sp.l: After the Prince got to the keepers lodge
And had been jocund in the house a while:
Tossing of ale and milk in country cans,
Whether it was the countries sweet content:
Or else the bonny damsel filled us drink
That seemed so stately in her stammel red:
Or that a qualm did cross his stomach then,
But straight he fell into his passions.

sp.speaker: Ermsbie.
sp.l: Sirrah Raphe, what say you to your master,
Shall he thus all amort live malcontent.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: Hearest thou Ned, nay look if he will speak to me.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: What sayst thou to me fool?

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: I prithee tell me Ned, art thou in love with the keepers daughter?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: How if I be, what then?

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: Why then sirrah I will teach thee how to deceive love.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: How Raphe.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: Marry sirrah Ned, thou shalt put on my cap, and my coat, and my dagger, and I will put on thy clothes, and thy sword, and so thou shalt be my fool.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: And what of this?

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p:
Why so thou shalt beguile Love, for Love is such a proud scab, that he will never meddle with fools nor children, Is
not Raphes counsel good Ned.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Tell me Ned lacie, didst thou mark the maid,
How lively in her country weeds she looked:
A bonier wench all Suffolke cannot yield,
All Suffolke, nay all England holds none such.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: sirrah, Will Ermsby, Ned is deceived.

sp.speaker: Ermsbie.
sp.p: Why Raphe?

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: He says all England hath no such, and I say, and I will stand to it, there is one better in Warwickshire.

sp.speaker: Warren.
sp.p: How provest thou that Raphe?

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: Why is not the Abbot a learned man, and hath red many books, and thinkest thou he hath not more learning than thou to choose a bonny wench, yes I warrant thee by his whole grammar.

sp.speaker: Ermsby.
sp.p: A good reason Raphe.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I tell thee Lacie, that her sparkling eyes,
Do lighten forth sweet Loves alluring fire:
And in her tresses she doth fold the looks
Of such as gaze upon her golden hair,
Her bashful white mixed with the mornings red,
Luna doth boast upon her lovely cheeks,
Her front is beauties table where she paints,
The glories of her gorgeous excellence:
Her teeth are shelves of precious Margarites,
Richly enclosed with ruddy curroll cleaves.
Tush Lacie, she is beauties overmatch,
If thou surveyest her curious imagery.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: I grant my lord the damsel is as fair,
As simple Suffolks homely towns can yield:
But in the court be quainter dames than she,
Whose faces are enriched with honours taint,
Whose beauties stand upon the stage of fame,
And vaunt their trophies in the courts of love.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Ah Ned, but hadst thou watched her as myself,
And seen the secret beauties of the maid,
Their courtly coyness were but foolery.

sp.speaker: Ermsbie.
sp.l: Why how watched you her my lord?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: When as she swept like Venus through the house,
And in her shape fast folded up my thoughts:
Into the Milkhouse went I with the maid,
And there amongst the cream-bowls she did shine,
As Palace, amongst her Princely housewifery:
She turned her smock over her Lily arms,
And dived them into milk to run her cheese:
But whiter than the milk her crystal skin,
Checked with lines of Azur made her blush,
That art or nature durst bring for compare,
Ermsbie if thou hadst seen as I did note it well,
How beauty played the housewife, how this girl
Like Lucrece laid her fingers to the work,
Thou wouldst with Tarquine hazard Rome and all
To win the lovely maid of Fresingfield.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: sirrah Ned, wouldst fain have her?

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p:
Why Ned I have laid the plot in my head thou
shalt have her already.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: I will give thee a new coat if learn me that.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: Why sirrah Ned we will ride to Oxford to Friar Bacon, o he is a brave scholar sirrah, they say he is a brave Nigromancer, that he can make women of devils, and he can juggle cats into Costermongers.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: And how then Raphe?

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p:
Marry sirrah thou shalt go to him, and because thy father
Harry shall not miss thee, he shall turn me into thee; and I will to the Court, and I will prince it out, and he shall make thee either a silken purse, full of gold, or else a fine wrought smock.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: But how shall I have the maid?

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: Marry sirrah, if thou beest a silken purse full of gold, then on sundays she will hang thee by her side, and you must not say a word, Now sir when she comes into a great press of people, for fear of the cutpurse on a sudden she will swap thee into her placard, then sirrah being there you may plead for yourself.

sp.speaker: Ermsbie.
sp.p: Excellent policy.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: But how if I be a wrought smock.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: Then she will put thee into her chest and lay thee into Lavender, and upon some good day she will put thee on, and at night when you go to bed, then being turned from a smock to a man, you may make up the match.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.p: Wonderfully wisely counselled Raphe.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Raphe shall have a new coat.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: God thank you when I have it on my back Ned,

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Lacie the fool hath laid a perfect plot,
For why our country Margret is so coy,
And stands so much upon her honest points,
That marriage or no market with the maid:
Ermsbie, it must be nigromatic spells,
And charms of art that must enchain her love,
Or else shall Edward never win the girl,
Therefore my wags we will horse us in the morn,
And post to Oxford to this jolly Friar,
Bacon shall by his magic do this deed.

sp.speaker: Warren.
sp.l: Content my lord, and that is a speedy way
To wean these headstrong puppies from the teat,

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: I am unknown, not taken for the Prince,
They only deem us frolic Courtiers,
That revel thus among our lieges game:
Therefore I have devised a policy,
Lacie, thou knowest next friday is Saint James,
And then the country flocks to Halston fair,
Then will the keepers daughter frolic there,
And overshine the troupe of all the maids,
That come to see, and to be seen that day.
Haunt thee disguised among the country swains,
Fain thou art a farmers son, not far from thence,
Espy her loves, and who she liketh best:
Coat him, and court her to control the clown,
Say that the Courtier attired all in green,
That helped her handsomely to run her cheese,
And filled her fathers lodge with venison,
Commends him, and sends fairings to herself,
Buy something worthy of her parentage,
Not worth her beauty for Lacie then the fair,
Affords no Jewel fitting for the maid:
And when thou talkest of me, note if she blush,
O then she loves, but if her cheeks wax pale,
Disdain it is. Lacie send how she fares,
And spare no time nor cost to win her loves.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: I will my lord so execute this charge,
As if that Lacie were in love with her.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Send letters speedily to Oxford of the news.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: And sirrah Lacie, buy me a thousand thousand million of fine bells.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.p: What wilt thou do with them Raphe?

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: Marry every time that Ned sighs for the keepers daughter, I will tie a bell about him, and so within three or four days I will send word to his father Harry, that his son and my master Ned is become Loves morris dance.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Well Lacie, look with care unto thy charge,
And I will haste to Oxford to the Friar,
That he by art, and thou by secret gifts,
Mayst make me lord of merry Fresingfield.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: God send your honour your hearts desire.

body.stage:
Exeunt.
Enter frier Bacon, and Miles his poore scholer with bookes vnder his arme>, with them Burden, Mason, Clement, three doctors.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.p: Miles where are you?

emph.foreign: Hic sum, doctissime and reuerendissime doctor.
Attulisti nos libros meos de Mecromantia.
Ecce quam bonum and quam iocundum, habitares libros in vnum.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Now masters of our Academic state,
That rule in Oxford Viceroys in your place,
Whose heads contain Maps of the liberal arts,
Spending your time in depth of learned skill,
Why flock you thus to bacon secret Cell,
A Friar newly stalled in Brazen nose,
Say what is your mind, that I may make reply.

sp.speaker: Burden.
sp.l: Bacon we hear, that long we have suspect,
That thou art read in Magics mystery,
In Pyromancy to divine by flames,
To tell by Hydromatic, ebbs, and tides,
By Aeromancy, to discover doubts,
To plain out questions, as Apollo did.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Well master Burden, what of all this?

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Marie sir he doth but fulfil by rehearsing of these names the Fable of the Fox and the grapes, that which is above us, pertains nothing to us.

sp.speaker: Burden.
sp.l: I tell thee Bacon, Oxford makes report,
Nay England, and the court of Henrie says,
Thou art making of a brazen head by art,
Which shall unfold strange doubts and Aphorisms,
And read a lecture in Philosophy,
And by help of Devils and ghastly fiends,
Thou meanest ere many years or days be past,
To compass England with a wall of brass.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: And what of this?

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: What of this master, why he doth speak mystically, for he knows if your skill fail to make a brazen head, yet mother waters strong ale will fit his turn to make him have a copper nose.

sp.speaker: Clement.
sp.l: Bacon we come not grieving at thy skill,
But joying that our Academy yields
A man supposed the wonder of the world,
For if thy cunning work these miracles,
England and Europe shall admire thy fame,
And Oxford shall in characters of brass,
And statues, such as were built up in rome,
Eternize Friar Bacon for his art.

sp.speaker: Mason.
sp.l: Then gentle Friar, tell us thy intent.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Seeing you come as friends unto the friar
Resolve you doctors, Bacon can by books,
Make storming Boreas thunder from his cave,
And dim fair Luna to a dark Eclipse,
The great arch-ruler, potentate of hell,
Trembles, when Bacon bids him, or his fiends,
Bow to the force of his Pentageron.
What art can work, the frolic friar knows,
And therefore will I turn my Magic books,
And strain out Nigromancy to the deep,
I have contrived and framed a head of brass,
(I made Belcephon hammer out the stuff)
And that by art shall read Philosophy,
And I will strengthen England by my skill,
That if ten Caesars lived and reigned in Rome,
With all the legions Europe doth contain,
They should not touch a grass of English ground,
The work that Ninus reared at Babylon,
The brazen walls framed by Semiramis,
Carved out like to the portal of the sun,
Shall not be such as rings the English strand:
From dover to the market place of Rie.

sp.speaker: Burden.
sp.p: Is this possible?

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: I will bring ye two or three witnesses.

sp.speaker: Burden.
sp.p: What be those?

sp.speaker: Miles
sp.p: Marry sir three or four as honest devils, and good companions as any be in hell.

sp.speaker: Mason.
sp.l: No doubt but magic may do much in this,
For he that reads but Mathematic rules,
Shall find conclusions that avail to work,
Wonders that pass the common sense of men.

sp.speaker: Burden.
sp.l: But Bacon roves a bow beyond his reach,
And tells of more than magic can perform:
Thinking to get a fame by fooleries,
Have I not past as far in state of schools:
And red of many secrets, yet to think,
That heads of Brass can utter any voice,
Or more, to tell of deep philosophy,
This is a fable Aesop had forgot.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Burden, thou wrongest me in detracting thus,
Bacon loves not to stuff himself with lies:
But tell me fore these Doctors if thou dare,
Of certain questions I shall move to thee.

sp.speaker: Burden.
sp.l: I will ask what thou can.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Marry sir he will straight be on your pickpack to know whether the feminine or the masculine gender be most worthy.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.p: Were you not yesterday master Burden at Henly upon the Thames?

sp.speaker: Burden.
sp.p: I was, what then?

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.p: What book studied you there on all night?

sp.speaker: Burden.
sp.p: I, none at all I red not there a line.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.p: Then doctors, Friar Bacons art knows naught.

sp.speaker: Clement.
sp.p: What say you to this master Burden doth he not touch you?

sp.speaker: Burden.
sp.p: I pass not of his frivolous speeches.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Nay master Burden, my master ere he hath done with you, will turn you from a doctor to a dunce, and shake you so small, that he will leave no more learning in you than is in Balaams Ass.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Masters, for that learned Burdens skill is deep,
And sore he doubts of Bacons Cabalism:
I will show you why he haunts to Henly oft,
Not doctors for to taste the fragrant air:
But there to spend the night in Alchemy,
To multiply with secret spells of art.
Thus private steals he learning from us all,
To prove my sayings true, I will show you straight,
The book he keeps at Henly for himself.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Nay now my master goes to conjurations, take heed.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.p: Masters stand full, fear not, I will show you but his book.

body.stage: Heere he coniures.
Enter a woman with a shoulder of mutton on a spit, and a Devil.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: O master cease your conjuration, or you spoil all, for here is a she-devil come with a shoulder of mutton on a spit, you have marred the devils supper, but no doubt he thinks our College fare is slender, and so hath sent you his cook with a shoulder of mutton to make it exceed.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: O where am I, or what is become of me.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.p: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: Hostess at Henly mistress of the Bell.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.p: How camest thou here?

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: As I was in the kitchen amongst the maids,
Spitting the meat against supper for my guess:
A motion moved me to look forth of door.
No sooner had I pried into the yard,
But straight a whirlwind hoisted me from thence,
And mounted me aloft unto the clouds:
As in a trance I thought nor feared naught,
Nor know I where or whether I was taken:
Nor where I am, nor what these persons be.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: No, know you not master Burden.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: O yes good sir, he is my daily guest,
What master Burden, it was but yesternight,
That you and I at Henly played at cards.

sp.speaker: Burden.
sp.p: I know not what we did, a pox of all conjuring Friars.

sp.speaker: Clement.
sp.p: Now jolly Friar tell us is this the book that Burden is so careful to look on?

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: It is, but Burden tell me now,
Thinkest thou that Bacons Micromanticke skill,
Cannot perform his head and wall of Brass,
When he can fetch thine hostess in such post.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: I will warrant you master, if master Burden could conjure as well as you, he would have his book every night from Henly to study on at Oxford.

sp.speaker: Mason.
sp.l: Burden what are you mated by this frolic Friar,
Look how he droops, his guilty conscience
Drives him to bash and makes his hostess blush.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Well mistress for I will not have you missed,
You shall to Henly to cheer up your guests
Fore supper gin, Burden bid her adieu,
Say farewell to your hostess fore she goes,
sirrah away, and set her safe at home.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: Master Burden, when shall we see you at Henly.

body.stage: Exeunt Hostesse and the Deuill.

sp.speaker: Burden.
sp.p: The devil take thee and Henly too.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Master shall I make a good motion.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Marry sir now that my hostess is gone to provide supper, conjure up another spirit, and send doctor Burden flying after.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Thus rulers of our Academic state,
You have seen the Friar frame his art by proof:
And as the college called Brazen nose,
Is under him and he the master there:
So surely shall this head of brass be framed,
And yield forth strange and uncouth Aphorisms:
And Hell and Heccate shall fail the Friar,
But I will circle England round with brass.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.l: So be it, et nunc et semper, Amen.

body.stage:
Exeunt omnes.
Enter Margaret the faire mayd of Fresingfield, with Thomas and Ione, and other clownes: Lacie disguised in countrie apparell.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: By my troth Margret here is a weather is able to make a man call his father whoreson, if this weather hold we shall have hay good cheap, and butter and cheese at Harlston will bear no price.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Thomas, maids when they come to see the fair,
Count not to make a cope for dearth of hay,
When we have turned our butter to the salt,
And set our cheese safely upon the racks,.
Then let our fathers price it as they please,
We country sluts of merry Fresingfield,
Come to buy needless noughts to make us fine,
And look that young men should be frank this day,
And court us with such fairings as they can,
Phaebus is blithe and frolic looks from heaven,
As when he courted lovely Semele:
Swearing the peddlers shall have empty packs,
If that fair weather may make chapmen buy.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: But lovely Peggie Semele is dead,
And therefore Phaebus from his palace pries,
And seeing such a sweet and seemly saint,
Shows all his glories for to court yourself.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: This is a fairing gentle sir indeed,
To sooth me up with such smooth flattery,
But learn of me your scoff is too broad before:
Well Ione our; beauties must abide their jests,
We serve the turn in jolly Fresingfield.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: Margret, a farmers daughter for a farmers son,
I warrant you the meanest of us both,
Shall have a mate to lead us from the Church:
But Thomas what is the news? what in a dump.
Give me your hand, we are near a peddlers shop,
Out with your purse we must have fairings now.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: Faith Ione and shall, I will bestow a fairing on you, and then we will to the Tavern, and snap off a pint of wine or two.

body.stage: All this while Lacie whispers Margret in the eare.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.p: Whence are you sir, of Suffolke, for your terms are finer than the common sort of men?

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Faith lovely girl, I am of Beckles by,
Your neighbour not above six miles from hence,
A farmers son that never was so quaint,
But that he could do curtsy to such dames:
But trust me Margret I am sent in charge,
From him that reveled in your fathers house,
And filled his Lodge with cheer and venison,
Attired in green, he sent you this rich purse:
His token, that he help you run your cheese,
And in the milkhouse chatted with yourself.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: To me, you forget, yourself.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Women are often weak in memory.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: O pardon sir, I call to mind the man,
It were little manners to refuse his gift,
And yet I hope he sends it not for love:
For we have little leisure to debate of that.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.p: What Margret blush not, maids must have their loves.

sp.speaker: Thomas.
sp.p: Nay by the mass she looks pale as if she were angry.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.p: sirrah are you of Beckls? I pray how doth goodman Cob, my father bought a horse of him, I will tell you Marget, it were good to be a gentleman's jade, for of all things the foul hilding could not abide a dungcart.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: How different is this farmer from the rest,
That erst as yet hath pleased my wandering sight,
His words are witty, quickened with a smile,
His curtsy gentle, smelling of the court,
Facill and debonair in all his deeds,
Proportioned as was Paris, when in gray,
He courted Aenon in the vale by Troy.
Great lords have come and pleaded for my love,
Who but the keepers lass of Fresingfield,
And yet methinks this Farmers jolly son,
Passeth the proudest that hath pleased mine eye.
But Peg disclose not that thou art in love,
And show as yet no sign of love to him,
Although thou well wouldst wish him for thy love
Keep that to thee till time doth serve thy turn,
To show the grief wherein thy heart doth burn.
Come Ione and Thomas, shall we to the fair,
You Beckls man will not forsake us now,

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Not whilst I may have such quaint girls as you,

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Well if you chance to come by Fresingfield,
Make but a step into the keepers lodge,
And such poor fare as Woodmen can afford,
Butter and cheese, cream, and fat venison,
You shall have store, and welcome therewithal.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Gramercy Peggie, look for me ear long.

body.stage: Exeunt omnes.
Enter Henry the third, the emperour, the king of Castile, Elinor his daughter, Iaques Vandermast a Germaine.

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.l: Great men of Europe, monarchs of the West,
Ringed with the walls of old Oceanus,
Whose lofty surges like the battlements,
That compassed high-built Babell in with towers,
Welcome my lords, welcome brave western kings,
To Englands shore, whose promontory cleaves,
Shows Albion is another little world,
Welcome says English Henrie to you all,
Chiefly unto the lovely Eleanour;
Who dared for Edwards sake cut through the seas,
And venture as Agenors damsel through the deep,
To get the love of Henries wanton son.

sp.speaker: Castile.
sp.l: Englands rich Monarch brave Plantagenet,
The Pyren mounts swelling above the clouds,
That ward the wealthy Castile in with walls,
Could not detain the beauteous Eleanour,
But hearing of the fame of Edwards youth,
She dared to brooke Neptunus haughty pride,
And bide the brunt of froward Eolus,
Then may fair England welcome her the more.

sp.speaker: Elinor.
sp.l: After that English Henrie by his lords,
Had sent prince Edwards lovely counterfeit,
A present to the Castile Elinor,
The comely portrait of so brave a man,
The virtuous fame discoursed of his deeds,
Edwards courageous resolution,
Done at the holy land fore Damas walls,
Led both mine eye and thoughts in equal links,
To like so the English Monarchs son,
That I attempted perils for his sake.

sp.speaker: Emperor.
sp.l: Where is the Prince, my lord?

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.l: He posted down, not long since from the court,
To Suffolke side, to merry Fremingham,
To sport himself amongst my fallow deer,
From thence by packets sent to Hampton house,
We hear the Prince is ridden with his lords,
To Oxford, in the Academy there,
To hear dispute amongst the learned men,
But we will send forth letters for my son,
To will him come from Oxford to the court.

sp.speaker: Empe.
sp.l: Nay rather Henrie let us as we be,
Ride for to visit Oxford with our train,
Fain would I see your Universities,
And what learned men your Academy yields,
From Haspurg have I brought a learned clarke,
To hold dispute with English Orators.
This doctor surnamed Iaques Vandermast,
A German born, past into Padua,
To Florence, and to fair Bolonia,
To Paris, Rheims, and stately Orleans,
And talking there with men of art, put down
The chiefest of them all in Aphorisms,
In Magic, and the Mathematic rules,
Now let us Henrie try him in your schools.

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.l: He shall my lord, this motion likes me well,
We will progress straight to Oxford with our trains,
And see what men our Academy brings.
And wonder Vandermast welcome to me
In Oxford shalt thou find a jolly friar,
Called Friar Bacon, Englands only flower
Set him but Non-plus in his magic spells,
And make him yield in Mathematic rules,
And for thy glory I will bind thy brows,
Not with a poets garland made of Bays,
But with a coronet of choicest gold,
Whilst then we fit to Oxford with our troupes,
Let us in and banquet in our English court.

body.stage: Exit.
Enter Raphe Simnell in Edwardes apparrell, Edward, Warren, Ermsby disguised.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: Where be these vagabond knaves that they attend no better on their master?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: If it please your honour we are all ready at an inch.

sp.speaker: Raphe
sp.p: sirrah Ned, I will have no more post horse to ride on, I will have another fetch.

sp.speaker: Ermsbie.
sp.p: I pray you how is that my Lord?

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: Marry sir, I will send to the Isle of Eely for four or five dozen of Geese, and I will have them tide six and six together with whipcord, Now upon their backs will I have a fair field bed, with a Canopy, and so when it is my pleasure I will flee into what place I please; this will be easy.

sp.speaker: Warren.
sp.p: Your honour hath said well, but shall we to Brazen nose College before we pull off our boots.

sp.speaker: Ermsbie.
sp.l: Warren well notioned, we will to the Friar
Before we revel it within the town.
Raphe see you keep your countenance like a Prince.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: Wherefore have I such a company of cutting knaves to wait upon me, but to keep and defend my countenance against all mine enemies: have you not good swords and bucklers.

body.stage: Enter Bacon and Miles.

sp.speaker: Ermsbie.
sp.p: Stay who comes here.

sp.speaker: Warren.
sp.p: Some scholar, and we will ask him where Friar Bacon is.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.p: Why thou arrant dunce shall I never make thee good scholar, doth not all the town cry out, and say, Friar Bacons subsizar is the greatest blockhead in all Oxford, why thou canst not speak one word of true Latin.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: No sir, yes what is this else; Ego sum tuus homo, I am your man, I warrant you sir as good Tullies phrase as any is in Oxford.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.p: Come on sirrah, what part of speech is Ego.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Ego, is I, marry nomen substantiuo, .

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.p: How prove you that?

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Why sir let him prove himself if he will, I can be hard felt and understood.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.p: O gross dunce.

body.stage: Here beate him.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Come let us break off this dispute between these two. sirrah, where is Brazen nose College.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Not far from Copper-smiths hall.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: What dost thou mock me.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Not I sir, but what would you at Brazen nose?

sp.speaker: Ermsbie.
sp.p: Marry we would speak with friar Bacon.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Whose men be you.

sp.speaker: Ermsbie.
sp.p: Marry scholar here is our master.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: sirrah I am the master of these good fellows, mayst thou not know me to be a Lord by my reparel.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Then here is good game for the hawk, for here is the master fool, and a covey of Coxcombs, one wise man I think would spring you all.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: God's wounds Warren kill him.

sp.speaker: Warren.
sp.p: Why Ned I think the devil be in my sheath, I cannot get out my dagger.

sp.speaker: Ermsbie.
sp.p: Nor I mine, 'Swounds Ned I think I am bewitched.

sp.speaker: Miles
sp.p: A company of scabs, the proudest of you all draw your weapon if he can,
sp.l: See how boldly I speak now my master is by.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I strive in vain, but if my sword be shut,
And conjured fast by magic in my sheath,
Villain here is my fist.

body.stage: Strike him a box on the eare.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: O I beseech you conjure his hands too, that he may not lift his arms to his head, for he is light fingered.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.l: Ned strike him, I will warrant thee by mine honour.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: What means the English prince to wrong my man,

sp.speaker: Edward
sp.l: To whom speakest thou.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: To thee.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Who art thou.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Could you not judge when all your swords grew fast,
That friar Bacon was not far from hence:
Edward king Henries son and Prince of Wales,
Thy fool disguised cannot conceal thyself,
I know both Ermsbie and the Sussex Earl,
Else Friar Bacon had but little skill.
Thou comest in post from merry Fresingfield,
Fast fancied to the keepers bonny lass,
To crave some succour of the jolly Friar,
And Lacie Earl of Lincoln hast thou left,
To treat fair Margret to allow thy loves:
But friends are men, and love can baffle lords.
The Earl doth woos and courts her for himself.

sp.speaker: Warren.
sp.l: Ned this is strange, the friar knoweth all.

sp.speaker: Ermsbie.
sp.l: Apollo could not utter more than this.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I stand amazed to hear this jolly Friar,
Tell even the very secrets of my thoughts:
But learned Bacon since thou knowest the cause,
Why I did post so fast from Fresingfield.
Help Friar at a pinch, that I may have
The love of lovely Margret to myself,
And as I am true Prince of Wales, I will give
Living and lands to strength thy college state.

sp.speaker: Warren.
sp.l: Good Friar help the Prince in this.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: Why servant Ned, will not the friar do it. Were not my sword glued to my scabbard by conjuration, I would cut off his head and make him do it by force.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: i'faith my lord, your manhood and your sword is all alike, they are so fast conjured that we shall never see them.

sp.speaker: Ermsbie.
sp.l: What doctor in a dump, tush help the prince,
And thou shalt see how liberal he will prove,

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Crave not such actions, greater dumps than these,
I will my lord strain out my magic spells,
For this day comes the earl to Fresingfield,
And fore that night shuts in the day with dark,
They will be betrothed each to other fast:
But come with me, we will to my study straight,
And in a glass prospective I will show
What is done this day in merry Fresingfield.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Gramercy Bacon, I will quite thy pain.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: But send your train my lord into the town,
My scholar shall go bring them to their Inn:
Mean while we will see the knavery of the earl.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Warren leave me and Ermsbie, take the fool,
Let him be master and go revel it,
Till I and Friar Bacon talk a while.

sp.speaker: Warren.
sp.l: We will my lord.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: Faith Ned and I will lord it out till thou comest, I will be Prince of Wales over all the black pots in Oxford.

body.stage: Exeunt. Bacon and Edward goes into the study.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Now frolic Edward, welcome to my Cell,
Here tempers Friar Bacon many toys:
And hold this place his consistory court,
Wherein the devils pleads homage to his words,
Within this glass prospective thou shalt see
This day what is done in merry Fresingfield,
Twixt lovely Peggie and the Lincoln earl.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Friar thou gladdest me, now shall Edward try,
How Lacie meaneth to his sovereign lord.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Stand there and look directly in the glass,

body.stage: Enter Margret and Frier Bungay.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: What sees my lord.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I see the keepers lovely lass appear,
As bright sun as the paramour of Mars,
Only attended by a jolly friar.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Sit still and keep the crystal in your eye,

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: But tell me friar Bungay is it true,
That this fair courteous country swain,
Who says his father is a farmer nigh,
Can be lord Lacie earl of Lincomshire.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: Peggie it is true, it is Lacie for my life,
Or else mine art and cunning both doth fail.
Left by prince Edward to procure his loves,
For he in green that holp you run your cheese,
Is son to Henry and the prince of Wales.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Be what he will his lure is but for lust.
But did lord Lacie like poor Margret,
Or would he deign to wed a country lass,
Friar, I would his humble handmaid be,
And for great wealth, quite him with curtsy.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: Why Margret dost thou love him.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: His personage like the pride of vaunting Troy,
Might well avouch to shadow Hellens cape:
His wit is quick and ready in conceit,
As Greece afforded in her chiefest prime
Courteous, ah Friar full of pleasing smiles,
Trust me I love too much to tell thee more,
Suffice to me he is Englands paramour.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: Hath not each eye that viewed thy pleasing face,
Surnamed thee fair maid of Fresingfield.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Yes Bungay, and would God the lovely Earl
Had that in esse, that so many sought.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: Fear not, the Friar will not be behind,
To show his cunning to entangle love.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I think the Friar courts the bonny wench,
Bacon, methinks he is a lusty churl.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Now look my lord.

body.stage: Enter Lacie.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: God's wounds Bacon here comes Lacie.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Sit still my lord and mark the comedy.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: Here is Lacie, Margret step aside awhile.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Daphne the damsel, that caught Phaebus fast,
And locked him in the brightness of her looks,
Was not so beauteous in Appollos eyes,
As is fair Margret to the Lincoln earl,
Recant thee Lacie thou art put in trust,
Edward thy sovereigns son hath chosen thee
A secret friend to court her for himself:
And darest thou wrong thy Prince with treachery.
Lacie, love makes no exception of a friend,
Nor deems it of a Prince, but as a man:
Honour bids thee control him in his lust,
His wooing is not for to wed the girl,
But to entrap her and beguile the lass:
Lacie thou lovest, then brooke not such abuse,
But wed her, and abide thy Princes frown:
For better die, than see her live disgraced.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Come Friar I will shake him from his dumps,
How cheer you sir, a penny for your thought:
You are early up, pray God it be the near,
What come from Beckles in a morn so soon.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Thus watchful are such men as live in love,
Whose eyes brooke broken slumbers for their sleep,
I tell thee Peggie since last Harlston fair,
My mind hath felt a heap of passions.

sp.speaker: Margret
sp.l: A trusty man that court it for your friend,
Woo you still for the courtier all in green.
I marvel that he sues not for himself.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Peggie, I pleaded first to get your grace for him,
But when mine eyes surveyed your beauteous looks
Love like a wag, straight dived into my heart,
And there did shrine the Idea of yourself:
Pity me though I be a farmers son,
And measure not my riches but my love.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: You are very hasty for to garden well,
Seeds must have time to sprout before they spring,
Love ought to creep as doth the dials shade,
For timely ripe is rotten too too soon.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: Deus hie, room for a merry Friar,
What youth of Beckles, with the keepers lass,
It is well, but tell me hear you any news.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: No, Friar what news.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: Hear you not how the pursuivants do post,
With proclamations through each country town:

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: For what gentle friar tell the news.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: Dwellest thou in Beckles and hearest not of these news,
Lacie the Earl of Lincoln is late fled
From Windsor court disguised like a swain,
And lurks about the country here unknown.
Henrie suspects him of some treachery,
And therefore doth proclaim in every way
That who can take the Lincoln earl, shall have
Paid in the Exchequer twenty thousand crowns.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: The earl of Lincoln, Friar thou art mad,
It was some other, thou mistakest the man:
The Earl of Lincoln, why it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Yes very well my lord, for you are he,
The keepers daughter took you prisoner,
Lord Lacie yield, I will be your jailer once.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: How familiar they be Bacon.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Sit still and mark the sequel of their loves.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Then am I double prisoner to thyself,
Peggie, I yield, but are these news in jest,

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: In jest with you, but earnest unto me:
For why, these wrongs do wring me at the heart,
Ah how these earls and noble men of birth,
Flatter and fain to forge poor women's ills.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Believe me lass, I am the Lincoln earl,
I not deny, but attired thus in rags
I lived disguised to win fair Peggies love.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: What love is there where wedding ends not love?

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: I meant fair girl to make thee Lacies wife.

sp.speaker: Margret
sp.l: I little think that earls will stoop so low,

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Say, shall I make thee countess ere I sleep.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Handmaid unto the earl so please himself
A wife in name, but servant in obedience.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: The Lincoln countess, for it shall be so,
I will plight the bands and seal it with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: God's wounds Bacon they kiss, I will stab them,

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: O hold your hands my lord it is the glass.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Choler to see the traitors agree so well,
Made me think the shadows substances.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: It were a long poniard my lord, to reach between
Oxford and Fresingfield, but sit still and see more.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: Well lord of Lincoln, if your loves be knit,
And that your tongues and thoughts do both agree:
To avoid ensuing jars, I will hamper up the match,
I will take my porteous forth, and wed you here,
Then go to bed and seal up your desires.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Friar content, Peggie how like you this?

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: What likes my lord is pleasing unto me.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: Then hand-fast hand, and I will to my book,

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: What sees my lord now.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Bacon, I see the lovers hand in hand,
The Friar ready with his porteous there,
To wed them both, then am I quite undone,
Bacon help now, if ere thy magic served,
Help Bacon, stop the marriage now,
If devils or nigromancy may suffice,
And I will give thee forty thousand crowns.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Fear not my lord, I will stop the jolly Friar,
For mumbling up his orisons this day.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Why speakest not Bungay, Friar to thy book.

body.stage: Bungay is mute, crying Hud hud.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: How lookest thou friar, as a man distraught,
Reft of thy senses Bungay, show by signs
If thou be dumb what passions holdeth thee.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: He is dumb indeed: Bacon hath with his devils
Enchanted him, or else some strange disease,
Or Apoplexy hath possessed his lungs:
But Peggie what he cannot with his book
We will twixt us both unite it up in heart.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Else let me die my lord a miscreant.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Why stands friar Bacon so amazed.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: I have struck him dumb my lord, and if your honour please
I will fetch this Bungay straightaway from Fresingfield,
And he shall dine with us in Oxford here.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Bacon, do that and thou contentest me,

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Of curtsy Margret let us lead the friar
unto thy fathers lodge, to comfort him
With broths to bring him from this hapless trance.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Or else my lord, we were passing unkind
To leave the friar so in his distress.

body.stage: Enter a deuill, and carrie Bungay on his backe.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: O help my lord, a devil, a devil my lord,
Look how he carries Bungay on his back:
Let us hence for Bacons spirits be abroad.

body.stage: Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Bacon I laugh to see the jolly Friar
Mounted upon the devil, and how the earl
Flees with his bonny lass for fear,
As soon as Bungay is at Brazen nose,
And I have chatted with the merry friar,
I will in post hie me to Fresingfield,
And quite these wrongs on Lacie ere it be long,

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: So be it my lord, but let us to our dinner:
For ere we have taken our repast awhile,
We shall have Bungay brought to Brazen nose.

body.stage: Exeunt. Enter three doctors, Burden, Mason, Clement.

sp.speaker: Mason.
sp.l: Now that we are gathered in the regent house,
It fits us talk about the kings repair,
For he trooped with all the western kings
That lie alongst the Dansick seas by East,
North by the clime of frosty Germany,
The Almain Monarch, and the Scocon duke,
Castile, and lovely Ellinor with him,
Have in their jests resolved for Oxford town.

sp.speaker: Burden.
sp.l: We must lay plots of stately tragedies,
Strange comic shows, such as proud Rossius
Vaunted before the Roman Emperors.

sp.speaker: Clement.
sp.l: To welcome all the western Potentates
But more the king by letters hath foretold,
That Fredericke the Almain Emperor
Hath brought with him a German of esteem,
Whose surname is Don Iaquesse Vandermast,
Skilful in magic and those secret arts.

sp.speaker: Mason.
sp.l: Then must we all make suit unto the friar,
To Friar Bacon that he vouch this task,
And undertake to countervail in skill
The German, else there is none in Oxford can,
Match and dispute with learned Vandermast.

sp.speaker: Burden.
sp.l: Bacon, if he will hold the German play,
We will teach him what an English Friar can do:
The devil I think dare not dispute with him.

sp.speaker: Clement.
sp.l: Indeed master doctor he pleasured you,
In that he brought your hostess with her spit,
From Henly posting unto Brazen nose.

sp.speaker: Burden.
sp.l: A vengeance on the Friar for his pains,
But leaving that, let us hie to Bacon straight,
To see if he will take this task in hand.

sp.speaker: Clement.
sp.p: Stay what rumour is this, the town is up in a mutiny, what hurly burly is this?

body.stage: Enter a Constable, with Raphe, Warren, Ermsbie and Miles.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: Nay masters if you were never so good, you shall before the doctors to answer your misdemeanour.

sp.speaker: Burden.
sp.p: What is the matter fellow?

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: Marie sir, here is a company of rufflers that drinking in the Tavern have made a great brawl, and almost killed the vintner.

sp.speaker: Miles
sp.l: Salue doctor Burden, this lubberly lurdan,
Ill shaped and ill faced, disdained and disgraced,
What he tells unto vobis, mentitur de nobis.

sp.speaker: Burden.
sp.l: Who is the master and chief of this crew?

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.l: Neat sheet and fine, as brisk as a cup of wine.

sp.speaker: Burden.
sp.p: What are you?

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: I am father doctor as a man would say, the Bellwether of this company, these are my lords, and I the prince of Wales.

sp.speaker: Clement.
sp.p: Are you Edward the kings son?

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: Sirrah Miles, bring hither the tapster that drew the wine, and I warrant when they see how soundly I have broke his head, they will say it was done by no less man than a prince.

sp.speaker: Mason.
sp.p: I cannot believe that this is the prince of Wales.

sp.speaker: Warren.
sp.p: And why so sir?

sp.speaker: Mason.
sp.l: For they say the prince is a brave and a wise gentleman.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Why and thinkest thou doctor that he is not so?
Darest thou detract and derogate from him,
Being so lovely and so brave a youth.

sp.speaker: Ermsbie.
sp.l: Whose face shining with many a sugared smile,
Bewrays that he is bred of princely race.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.l: And yet master doctor, to speak like a proctor,
And tell unto you, what is veriment and true,
To cease of this quarrel, look but on his apparel,
Then mark but my talis, he is great prince of Walis,
The chief of our gregis, and filius regis,
Then ware what is done, for he is Henries white son.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p:
Doctors whose doting nightcaps are not capable of my ingenious dignity, know that I am Edward Plantagenet, whom if you displease, will make a ship that shall hold all your
colleges, and so carry away the university with a fair wind, to the Bankeside in Southwarke, how sayst thou Ned Warraine, shall I not do it?

sp.speaker: Warren.
sp.p: Yes my good lord, and if it please your lordship, I will gather up all your old pantofles, and with the cork, make you a Pinnace of five hundred tonne, that shall serve the turn marvelous well, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ermsbie.
sp.p: And I my lord will have Pioneers to undermine the town, that the very Gardens and orchards be carried away for your summer walks.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.l: And I with scientia and great diligentia,
Will conjure and charm, to keep you from harm,
That vtrum horum mauis, your very great nauis,
Like Bartlets ship, from Oxford do skip,
With Colleges and schools, full laden with fools,

l.emph: Quid dices ad hoc, worshipful domine Dawcock.

sp.speaker: Clement.
sp.l: Why harebrained courtiers, are you drunk or mad,
To taunt us up with such scurrility,
Deem you us men of base and light esteem,
To bring us such a fop for Henries son,
Call out the beadles and convey them hence,
Straight to Bocardo, let the roisters lie
Close clapped in bolts, until their wits be tame.

sp.speaker: Ermsbie.
sp.p: Why shall we to prison my lord?

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: What sayst Miles, shall I honour the prison with my presence?

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.l: No, no, out with your blades, and hamper these jades,
Have a flirt and a crash, now play revel dash,
And teach these Sacerdos, that the Bocardos,
Like peasants and elves, are meet for themselves.

sp.speaker: Mason.
sp.p: To the prison with them constable.

sp.speaker: Warren.
sp.l: Well doctors seeing I have sported me,
With laughing at these mad and merry wags,
Know that prince Edward is at Brazen nose,
And this attired like the prince of Wales,
Is Raphe, king Henries only loved fool,
I, earl of Essex, and this Ermsbie
One of the privy chamber to the king,
Who while the prince with Friar Bacon stays,
Have reveled it in Oxford as you see.

sp.speaker: Mason.
sp.l: My lord pardon us, we knew not what you were,
But courtiers may make greater scapes than these,
Will it please your honour dine with me today?

sp.speaker: Warren.
sp.p: I will master doctor, and satisfy the vintner for his hurt, only I must desire you to imagine him all this forenoon the prince of Wales.

sp.speaker: Mason.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: And upon that I will lead the way, only I will have Miles go before me, because I have heard Henrie say, that wisdom must go before Majesty.

body.stage: Exeunt omnes.
Enter prince Edward with his poinard in his hand, Lacie and Margret.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Lacie thou canst not shroud thy traitorous thoughts,
Nor cover as did Cassius all his wiles,
For Edward hath an eye that looks as far,
As Lincaeus from the shores of Grecia,
Did not I sit in Oxford by the Friar,
And see thee court the maid of Fresingfield
Sealing thy flattering fancies with a kiss,
Did not proud Bungay draw his porteous forth,
And joining hand in hand had married you,
If Friar Bacon had not stroke him dumb,
And mounted him upon a spirits back,
That we might chat at Oxford with the friar,
Traitor what answerest, is not all this true?

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Truth all my Lord and thus I make reply,
At Harlstone fair there courting for your grace,
When as mine eye surveyed her curious shape,
And drew the beauteous glory of her looks,
To dive into the centre of my heart.
Love taught me that your honour did but jest,
That princes were in fancy but as men,
How that the lovely maid of Fresingfield,
Was fitter to be Lacies wedded wife,
Than concubine unto the prince of Wales.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Injurious Lacie did I love thee more
Than Alexander his Hephestion,
Did I unfold the passion of my love,
And lock them in the closet of thy thoughts,
Wert thou to Edward second to himself,
Sole friend, and partner of his secret loves,
And could a glance of fading beauty break,
The enchained fetters of such private friends,
Base coward, false, and too effeminate,
To be co-rival with a prince in thoughts,
From Oxford have I posted since I dined,
To quite a traitor fore that Edward sleep.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: It was I my Lord, not Lacie stepped awry,
For oft he sued and courted for yourself,
And still wood for the courtier all in green,
But I whom fancy made but overfond,
Pleaded myself with looks as if I loved,
I fed mine eye with gazing on his face,
And still bewitched loved Lacie with my looks,
My heart with sighs, mine eyes pleaded with tears,
My face held pity and content at once,
And more I could not cipher out by signs
But that I loved Lord Lacie with my heart,
Then worthy Edward measure with thy mind,
If women's favours will not force men fall,
If beauty and if darts of piercing love,
Is not of force to bury thoughts of friends.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I tell thee Peggie I will have thy loves,
Edward or none shall conquer Margret,
In Frigates bottomed with rich Sethin planks,
Topped with the lofty firs of Libanon,
Stemmed and encased with burnished Ivory
And overlaid with plates of Persian wealth,
LIke Thetis shalt thou wanton on the waves
And draw the Dolphins to thy lovely eyes,
To dance lauoltas in the purple streams,
Sirens with harps and silver psalteries,
Shall weight with music at thy frigates stem,
And entertain fair Margret with her lays,
England and Englands wealth shall wait on thee,
Britain shall bend unto her princes love,
And do due homage to thine excellence,
If thou wilt be but Edwards Margret.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Pardon my lord if loves great royalty,
Sent me such presents as to Danae,
If Phoebus tied in Latonas webs,
Come courting from the beauty of his lodge,
The dulcet tunes of frolic Mercury,
Not all the wealth heavens treasury affords,
Should make me leave lord Lacie or his love.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I have learned at Oxford then this point of schools.
Lacie the cause that Margret cannot love,
Nor fix her liking on the English Prince,
Take him away, and then the effects will fail,
Villain prepare thyself for I will bathe
My poniard in the bosom of an earl.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Rather than live, and miss fair Margrets love,
Prince Edward stop not at the fatal doom,
But stab it home, end both my loves and life.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Brave Prince of Wales, honoured for royal deeds,
It were sin to stain fair Venus courts with blood,
Loves conquests ends my Lord in curtsy,
Spare Lacie gentle Edward, let me die,
For so both you and he do cease your loves.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Lacie shall die as traitor to his Lord.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: I have deserved it, Edward act it well.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: What hopes the Prince to gain by Lacies death?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: To end the loves twixt him and Margeret.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Why, thinks king Henries son that Margrets love,
Hangs in the uncertain balance of proud time,
That death shall make a discord of our thoughts,
No, stab the earl, and fore the morning sun
Shall vaunt him thrice, over the lofty east,
Margret will meet her Lacie in the heavens.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: If ought betides to lovely Margret,
That wrongs or wrings her honour from content,
Europes rich wealth nor Englands monarchy,
Should not allure Lacie to overlive,
Then Edward short my life and end her loves.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Rid me, and keep a friend worth many loves.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Nay Edward keep a love worth many friends.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: And if thy mind be such as fame hath blazed,
Then princely Edward let us both abide
The fatal resolution of thy rage,
Banish thou fancy, and embrace revenge,
And in one tomb knit both our carcasses,
Whose hearts were linked in one perfect love,

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Edward Art thou that famous prince of Wales,
Who at Damasco beat the Saracens,
And broughtst home triumph on thy lances point,
And shall thy plumes be pulled by Venus down,
Is it princely to dissever lovers leagues,
To part such friends as glory in their loves,
Leave Ned, and make a virtue of this fault,
And further Peg and Lacie in their loves,
So in subduing fancies passion,
Conquering thyself thou gettest the richest spoil,
Lacie rise up, fair Peggie here is my hand,
The prince of Wales hath conquered all his thoughts
And all his loves he yields unto the earl,
Lacie enjoy the maid of Fresingfield,
Make her thy Lincoln countess at the church,
And Ned as he is true Plantagenet,
Will give her to thee frankly for thy wife.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Humbly I take her of my sovereign,
As if that Edward gave me Englands right,
And riched me with the Albion diadem.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: And doth the English Prince mean true,
Will he vouchsafe to cease his former loves,
And yield the title of a country maid,
unto lord Lacie.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I will fair Peggie as I am true lord.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Then lordly sir, whose conquest is as great,
In conquering love as Caesars victories,
Margret as mild and humble in her thoughts,
As was Aspatia unto Cirus self,
Yields thanks, and next lord Lacie, doth enshrine
Edward the second secret in her heart.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Gramercy Peggie, now that vows are past,
And that your loves are not be revolt:
Once Lacie friends again, come we will post
To Oxford, for this day the king is there,
And brings for Edward Castile Ellinor.
Peggie I must go see and view my wife,
I pray God I like her as I loved thee.
Beside, lord Lincoln we shall hear dispute,
Twixt friar Bacon, and leaned Vandermast,
Peggie we will leave you for a week or two.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: As it please lord Lacie, but loves foolish looks,
Think footsteps Miles, and minutes to be hours.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: I will hasten Peggie to make short return,
But please your honour go unto the lodge,
We shall have butter, cheese, and venison.
And yesterday I brought for Margret,
A lusty bottle of neat claret wine,
Thus can we feast and entertain your grace.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: It is cheer lord Lacie for an Emperor,
If he respect the person and the place:
Come let us in, for I will all this night,
Ride post until I come to Bacons cell.

body.stage: Exeunt. Enter Henrie, Emperour, Castile, Ellinor, Vandermast, Bungay

sp.speaker: Emperor.
sp.l: Trust me Plantagenet these Oxford schools
Are richly seated near the river side:
The mountains full of fat and fallow deer,
The battling pastures laid with kine and flocks,
The town gorgeous with high built colleges,
And scholars seemly in their grave attire.
Learned in searching principles of art,
What is thy judgment, Iaquis Vandermast.

sp.speaker: Vandermast.
sp.l: That lordly are the buildings of the town,
Spacious the rooms and full of pleasant walks:
But for the doctors how that they be learned,
It may be meanly, for aught I can hear.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: I tell thee Germane, Haspurge holds none such,
None red so deep as Oxenford contains,
There are within our academic state,
Men that may lecture it in Germany,
To all the doctors of your Belgicke schools.

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.l: Stand to him Bungay, charm this Vandermast,
And I will use thee as a royal king.

sp.speaker: Vandermast.
sp.l: Wherein darest thou dispute with me.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: In what a Doctor and a Friar can.

sp.speaker: Vandermast.
sp.l: Before rich Europes worthies put thou forth
The doubtful question unto Vandermast.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.p: Let it be this, whether the spirits of Pyromancy or Geomancy, be most predominant in magic.

sp.speaker: Vander.
sp.l: I say of Pyromancy.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: And I of Geomancy.

sp.speaker: Vander.
sp.l: The cabalists that wright of magic spells,
As Hermes, Melchie, and Pithagoras,
Affirm that amongst the quadruplicity
Of elemental essence, Terra is but thought,
To be a punctum squared to the rest:
And that the compass of ascending elements
Exceed in bigness as they do in height.
Judging the concave circle of the sun,
To hold the rest in his circumference,
If then as Hermes says the fire be greatest,
Purest and only giveth shapes to spirits:
Then must these Demons that haunt that place,
Be every way superior to the rest.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: I reason not of elemental shapes,
Nor tell I of the concave latitudes,
Noting their essence nor their quality,
But of the spirits that Pyromancy calls,
And of the vigour of the Geomantic fiends,
I tell thee Germane magic haunts the grounds,
And those strange necromantic spells
That work such shows and wondering in the world,
Are acted by those Geomantic spirits,
That Hermes calleth Terra filii.
The fiery spirits are but transparent shades,
That lightly pass as Heralds to bear news,
But earthly fiends closed in the lowest deep,
Dissever mountains if they be but charged,
Being more gross and massy in their power.

sp.speaker: Vander.
sp.l: Rather these earthly geomantic spirits,
Are dull and like the place where they remain:
For when proud Lucifer fell from the heavens,
The spirits and angels that did sin with him,
Retained their local essence as their faults,
All subject under Lunas continent,
They which offended less hang in the fire,
And second faults did rest within the air,
But Lucifer and his proud hearted fiends,
Were thrown into the centre of the earth,
Having less understanding than the rest,
As having greater sin, and lesser grace.
Therefore such gross and earthly spirits do serve,
For Jugglers, Witches, and vild sorcerers,
Whereas the Pyromantic genii,
Are mighty, swift, and of far reaching power,
But grant that Geomancy hath most force,
Bungay to please these mighty potentates,
Prove by some instance what thy art can do.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Emper.
sp.l: Now English Harry here begins the game,
We shall see sport between these learned men.

sp.speaker: Vandermast.
sp.l: What wilt thou do.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: Show thee the tree leaved with refined gold,
Whereon the fearful dragon held his seat,
That watched the garden called Hesperides,
Subdued and won by conquering Hercules.

sp.speaker: Vandermast.
sp.l: Well done.

body.stage: Heere Bungay coniures and the tree appeares with the dragon shooting fire.

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.l: What say you royal lordings to my friar,
Hath he not done a point of cunning skill.

sp.speaker: Vander.
sp.l: Each scholar in the Necromantic spells,
Can do as much as Bungay hath performed,
But as Alcmenas bastard raised this tree,
So will I raise him up as when he lived,
And cause him pull the Dragon from his seat,
And tear the branches piecemeal from the root,
Hercules Prodie, Prodi Hercules.

body.stage: Hercules appeares in his Lions skin.

sp.speaker: Vandermast.
sp.l: Jove's bastard son thou libian Hercules
Pull off the sprigs from off the Hesperian tree,
As once thou didst to win the golden fruit.

body.stage: Heere he begins to breake the branches.

sp.speaker: Vander.
sp.l: Now Bungay if thou canst by magic charm,
The fiend appearing like great Hercules,
From pulling down the branches of the tree,
Then art thou worry to be counted learned.

sp.speaker: Bugay.
sp.l: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Vander.
sp.l: Cease Hercules until I give thee charge,
Mighty commander of this English Isle,
Henrie come from the stout Plantagenets,
Bungay is learned enough to be a Friar.
But to compare with Iaquis Vandermast,
Oxford and Cambridge must go seek their cells,
To find a man to match him in his art.
I have given non-plus to the Paduans,
To them of Sien, Florence, and Belogna,
Reimes, Louain and fair Rotherdam,
Franckford, Lurrech and Orleance:
And now must Henrie if he do me right,
Crown me with laurel as they all have done.

body.stage: Enter Bacon.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: All hail to this royal company,
That sit to hear and see this strange dispute:
Bungay, how standest thou as a man amazed,
What hath the Germane acted more than thou,

sp.speaker: Vandermast.
sp.l: What art thou that questions thus.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Men all me Bacon.

sp.speaker: Vander.
sp.l: Lordly thou lookest, as if that thou wert learned,
Thy countenance, as if science held her seat
Between the circle arches of thy brows.

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.l: Now Monarchs hath the German found his match.

sp.speaker: Emperor.
sp.l: Bestir thee Iaquis take not now the foil,
Lest thou dost lose what foretime thou didst gain.

sp.speaker: Vandermast.
sp.l: Bacon, wilt thou dispute.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: No, unless he were more learned than Vandermast.
For yet tell me, what hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Vandermast.
sp.l: Raised Hercules to ruinate that tree,
That Bungay mounted by his magic spells.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Set Hercules to work.

sp.speaker: Vander.
sp.l: Now Hercules, I charge thee to thy task,
Pull off the golden branches from the root.

sp.speaker: Hercules.
sp.l: I dare not, Seest thou not great Bacon here,
Whose frown doth act more than thy magic can.

sp.speaker: Vandermast.
sp.l: By all the thrones and dominations,
Virtues, powers and mighty Hierarchies,
I charge thee to obey to Vandermast.

sp.speaker: Hercules.
sp.l: Bacon, that bridles headstrong Belcephon,
And rules Asmenoth guider of the North:
Binds me from yielding unto Vandermast.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: How now Vandermast, have you met with your match.

sp.speaker: Vandermast.
sp.l: Never before was it known to Vandermast,
That men held devils in such obedient awe,
Bacon doth more than art or else I fail.

sp.speaker: Emperor.
sp.l: Why Vandermast art thou overcome,
Bacon dispute with him, and try his skill:

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: I come not Monarchs for to hold dispute,
With such a novice as is Vandermast,
I come to have your royalties to dine
With Friar Bacon here in Brazen nose,
And for this Germane troubles but the place
And holds this audience with along suspense,
I will send him to his academy hence,
Thou Hercules whom Vandermast did raise,
Transport the Germane into Haspurge straight,
That he may learn by travail against the springs,
More secret dooms and Aphorisms of art,
Vanish the tree and thou away with him.

body.stage: Exit the spirit with Vandermast and the Tree.

sp.speaker: Emperor.
sp.l: Why Bacon whether dost thou send him,

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: To Haspurge there your highness at return,
Shall find the Germane in his study safe.

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.l: Bacon, thou hast honoured England with thy skill,
And made fair Oxford famous by thine art,
I will be English Henrie to thyself,
But tell me shall we dine with thee today.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: With me my Lord, and while I fit my cheer,
See where Prince Edward comes to welcome you:
Gracious as the morning star of heaven,

body.stage:
Exit.
Enter Edward, Lacie, Warren, Ermsbie.

sp.speaker: Emperor.
sp.l: Is this Prince Edward Henries royal son,
How martial is the figure of his face,
Yet lovely and beset with Amorets.

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.l: Ned, where hast thou been.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: At Framingham my Lord, to try your bucks.
If they could scape they teasers or the toil:
But hearing of these lordly Potentates
Landed, and progressed up to Oxford town,
I posted to give entertain to them,
Chief to the Almain Monarch, next to him,
And joint with him, Castile and Saxonie,
Are welcome as they may be to the English Court.
Thus for the men, but see Venus appears,
Or one that overmatched Venus in her shape,
Sweet Ellinor, beauties high swelling pride,
Rich natures glory, and her wealth at once:
Fair of all fairs, welcome to Albion,
Welcome to me, and welcome to thine own,
If that thou deignest the welcome from myself.

sp.speaker: Ellinor.
sp.l: Martial Plantagenet, Henries high minded son,
The mark that Ellinor did count her aim,
I liked thee fore I saw thee, now I love,
And so as in so short a time I may:
Yet so as time shall never break that so,
And therefore so accept of Ellinor.

sp.speaker: Castile.
sp.l: Fear not my Lord, this couple will agree,
If love may creep into their wanton eyes:
And therefore Edward I accept thee here,
Without suspense, as my adopted son.

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.l: Let me that joy in these comforting greets,
And glory in these honours done to Ned,
Yield thanks for all these favours to my son,
And rest a true Plantagenet to all.

body.stage: Enter Miles with a cloth and trenchers and salt.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Saluete omnes reges, that govern your Greges, in Saxonie and Spain, in England and in Almain: for all this frolic rabble must I cover thee table, with trenchers, salt and cloth, and then look for your broth.

sp.speaker: Emperor.
sp.p: What pleasant fellow is this.

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.p: It is my lord, doctor Bacons poor scholar.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p:
My master hath made me sewer of these great lords, and God knows I am as serviceable at a table, as a sow is under
an apple tree: it is no matter, their cheer shall not be great, and therefore what skills where the salt stand before or behind.

sp.speaker: Castile.
sp.l: These scholars knows more skill in axioms,
How to use quips and sleights of Sophistry,
Than for to cover courtly for a king.

body.stage: Enter Miles with a messe of pottage and broth, and after him Bacon.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Spill sir, why do you think I never carried twopenny chop before in my life: by your leave, Nobile decus, for here comes doctor Bacons pecus, being in his full age, to carry a mess of pottage.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Lordings admire not if your cheer be this,
For we must keep our academic fare,
Not riot where Philosophy doth rain,
And therefore Henrie place these Potentates,
And bid them fall unto their frugal cates.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Presumptuous Friar, what scoffest thou at a king,
What dost thou taunt us with thy peasants fare,
And give us cates fit for country swains,
Henrie proceeds this jest of thy consent,
To twit us with such a pittance of such price,
Tell me, and Fredericke will not grieve the long.

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.l: By Henries honour and the royal faith
The English monarch beareth to his friend:
I knew not of the friars feeble fare,
Nor am I pleased he entertains you thus.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Content thee Fredericke for I showed the cates
To let thee see how scholars use to feed:
How little meat refines our English wits,
Miles take away, and let it be thy dinner.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.l: Marry sir I will, this day shall be a festival day with me,
For I shall exceed in the highest degree.

body.stage: Exit Miles.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: I tell thee Monarch, all the Germane Peers
Could not afford thy entertainment such,
So royal and so full of Majesty,
As Bacon will present to Fredericke,
The Basest waiter that attends thy cups,
Shall be in honours greater than thyself:
And for thy cates rich Alexandria drugs,
Fetched by Carueils from Egypt's richest straights:
Found in the wealthy strand of Africa,
Shall royalize the table of my king,
Wines richer than the Gyptian courtesan,
Quaffed to Augustus kingly countermatch,
Shall be caroused in English Henries feasts:
Candy shall yield the richest of her canes,
Persia down her volga by Canoes,
Send down the secrets of her spicery.
The Africke Dates mirabiles of Spain,
Conserves, and Suckets from Tiberias,
Cates from Iudea choicer than the lamp
That fired Rome with spakes of gluttony,
Shall beautify the board for Fredericke,
And therefore grudge not a friars feast.

body.stage: Enter two gentlemen, Lambert, and Serlby with the keeper.

sp.speaker: Lambert.
sp.l: Come frolic keeper of our lieges game,
Whose table spread hath ever venison,
And Jacks of wines to welcome passengers,
Know I am in love with jolly Margret,
That overshines our damsels as the moon,
Darkeneth the brightest sparkles of the night,
In laxfield here my land and living lies,
I will make thy daughter jointer of it all,
So thou consent to give her to my wife,
And I can spend five hundredth marks a year.

sp.speaker: Serlbie.
sp.l: I am the landlord keeper of thy holds,
By copy all thy living lies in me.
Lexfield did never see me raise my due,
I will enfeoff fair Margret in all,
So she will take her to a lusty squire.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: Now courteous gentles, if the Keepers girl,
Hath pleased the liking fancy of you both,
And with her beauty hath subdued your thoughts,
It is doubtful to decide the question.
It joys me that such men of great esteem,
Should lay their liking on this base estate,
And that her state should grow so fortunate,
To be a wife to meaner men than you.
But sith such squires will stoop to keepers fee,
I will to avoid displeasure of you both,
Call Margret forth, and she shall make her choice,

body.stage: Exit.

sp.speaker: Lambert.
sp.l: Content Keeper send her unto us.
Why Serlsby is thy wife so lately dead,
Are all thy loves so lightly passed over,
As thou canst wed before the year be out,

sp.speaker: Serlsby.
sp.l: I live not Lambert to content the dead,
Nor was I wedded but for life to her,
The graves ends and begins a married state.

body.stage: Enter Margret.

sp.speaker: Lambert.
sp.l: Peggie the lovely flower of all towns,
Suffolks fair Hellen, and rich Englands star,
Whose beauty tempered with her housewifery,
Makes England talk of merry Frisingfield.

sp.speaker: Serlsby.
sp.l: I cannot trick it up with poesies,
Nor paint my passions with comparisons,
Nor tell a tale of Phebus and his loves,
But this believe me Laxfield here is mine,
Of ancient rent seven hundred pounds a year,
And if thou canst but love a country squire,
I will enfeoff thee Margret in all,
I cannot flatter, try me if thou please.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Brave neighbouring squires the stay of Suffolks clime,
A Keepers daughters is too base in degree
To match with men accompted of such worth,
But might I not displease I would reply,

sp.speaker: Lambert.
sp.l: Say Peggy naught shall make us discontent.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Then gentles note that love hath little stay,
Nor can the flames that Venus sets on fire,
Be kindled but by fancies motion,
Then pardon gentles, if a maids reply
Be doubtful, while I have debated with myself,
Who or of whom love shall constrain me like,

sp.speaker: Serlsbie.
sp.l: Let it be me and trust me Margret,
The meats environed with the silver streams,
Whose Battling pastures fateneth all my flocks,
Yielding forth fleeces stapled with such wool,
As Lempster cannot yield more finer stuff
And forty kine with fair and burnished heads,
With strutting dugs that paggle to the ground,
Shall serve thy dowry if thou wed with me.

sp.speaker: Lambert.
sp.l: Let pass the country wealth as flocks and kine,
And lands that wave with Cere golden sheaves
filling my barns with plenty of the fields,
But peggie if thou wed thyself to me,
Thou shalt have garments of Embroidered silk,
Lawns and rich networks for thy head attire
Costly shall be thy fare habiliments,
If thou wilt be but Lamberts loving wife.

sp.speaker: Margret
sp.l: Content you gentles you have proffered fair,
And more than fits a country maids degree,
But give me leave to counsel me a time,
For fancy blooms not at the first assault,
Give me but ten days respite and I will reply,
Which or to whom myself affectionates.

sp.speaker: Serslby.
sp.l: Lambert I tell thee thou art importunate,
Such beauty fits not such a base esquire
It is for Serlsby to have Margret.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Thinkst thou with wealth to overreach me
Serlsby, I scorn to brooke thy country braves
I dare thee Coward to maintain this wrong,
At dint of rapier single in the field.

sp.speaker: Serlsby
sp.l: I will answer Lambert what I have avouched
Margret farewell, another time shall serve.

body.stage: Exit Serlsby

sp.speaker: Lambert.
sp.l: I will follow Peggie farewell to thyself,
Listen how well I will answer for thy love.

body.stage: Exit Lambert

sp.speaker: Margeret.
sp.l: How Fortune tempers lucky haps with frowns,
And wrongs me with the sweets of my delight,
Love is my bliss, and love is now my bale,
Shall I be Hellen in my forward fates,
As I am Hellen in my matchless hue
And set rich Suffolke with my face afire,
If lovely Lacie were but with his Peggy,
The cloudy darkness of his bitter frown
Would check the pride of these aspiring squires,
Before the term of ten days be expired,
When as they look for answer of their loves,
My Lord will come to merry Frisingfield,
And end their fancies, and their follies both,
Till when Peggie be blithe and of good cheer.

body.stage: Enter a post with a letter and a bag of gold.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Fair lovely damsel which; way leads this path,
How might I post me unto Frisingfield,
which; footpath leadeth to the keepers lodge?

sp.speaker: Margeret
sp.l: Your way is ready and this path is right,
Myself do dwell hereby in Frisingfield,
And if the keeper be the man you seek,
I am his daughter may I know the cause?

sp.speaker: Post
sp.l: Lovely and once beloved of my lord,
no marvel if his eye was lodged so low,
when brighter beauty is not in the heavens,
The Lincoln earl hath sent you letters here,
And with them, just an hundred pounds in gold,
Sweet bonny wench read them and make reply.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: The scrolls that Jove sent Danae
Wrapped in rich closures of fine burnished gold,
Were not more welcome than these lines to me.
Tell me whilst that I do unrip the seals,
Lives Lacie well, how fares my lovely Lord?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Well, if that wealth may make men to live well.

body.stage: The letter, and Margret reads it.

sp.p:
The blooms of the Almond tree grow in a night, and vanish in a morn, the flies Haemere (fair Peggie) take life with the Sun, and die with the dew, fancy that slippeth in with a gaze, goeth out with a wink, and too timely loves, have ever the shortest length. I write this as thy grief, and my folly, who at Frisingfield loved that which time hath taught me to be but mean dainties, eyes are dissemblers, and fancy is but queasy, therefore know Margret, I have chosen a Spanish Lady to be my wife, chief waiting woman to the Princess Ellinour, a Lady fair,
and no less fair than thyself, honourable and wealthy, in that I forsake thee I leave thee to thine own liking, and for thy dowry I have sent thee an hundred pounds, and ever assure thee of my favour, which shall avail thee and thine much. Farewell.
Not thine nor his own,

sp.l: Fond Atae doomer of bad boding fates,
That wraps proud Fortune in thy snaky locks,
Didst thou enchant my birthday with such stars,
As lightened mischief from their infancy,
If heavens had vowed, if stars had made decree,
To show on me their froward influence,
If Lacie had but loved, heavens hell and all,
Could not have wronged the patience of my mind.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: It grieves me damsel, but the Earl is forced
To love the Lady, by the Kings command.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: The wealth combined within the English shelves,
Europes commander nor the English King,
Should not have moved the love of Peggie from her Lord.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: What answer shall I return to my Lord?

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: First for thou camest from Lacie whom I loved,
Ah give me leave to sigh at every thought,
Take thou my friend the hundred pound he sent,
For Margrets resolution craves no dower,
The world shall be to her as vanity,
Wealth trash, love hate, pleasure despair,
For I will straight to stately Fremingham,
And in the abbey there be shorn a Nun
And yield my loves and liberties to God,
Fellow I give thee this, not for the news,
For those be hateful unto Margret,
But for thou art Lacies man once Margrets love.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: What I have heard what passions I have seen
I will make report of them unto the Earl.

body.stage: Exit Post

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Say that she joys his fancies be at rest,
And prays that his misfortune may be hers.

body.stage: Exit. Enter Frier Bacon drawing the curtaines with a white sticke, a booke in his hand, and a lampe lighted by him, and the brasen head and miles, whith weapons by him.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.p: Miles where are you?

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.p: How chance you tarry so long?

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Think you that the watching of the brazen head craves no furniture? I warrant you sir I have so armed myself, that if all your devils come I will not fear them an inch.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Miles thou knowest that I have dived into hell,
And sought the darkest palaces of fiends,
That with my Magic spells great Belcephon,
Hath left his lodge and kneeled at my cell,
The rafters of the earth rent from the poles,
And three-formed Luna hid her silver looks,
Trembling upon her concave continent,
When Bacon red upon his Magic book,
With seven years tossing nigromantic charms,
Poring upon dark Hecats principles,
I have framed out a monstrous head of brass,
That by the enchanting forces of the devil,
Shall tell out strange and uncouth Aphorisms,
And girt fair England with a wall of brass,
Bungay and I have watched these threescore days,
And now our vital spirits crave some rest,
If Argos lived and had his hundred eyes,
They could not overwatch Phobeters night,
Now Miles in thee rests Friar Bacons weal,
The honour and renowned of all his life,
Hangs in the watching of this brazen head,
Therefore I charge thee by the immortal God
That holds the souls of men within his fist,
This night thou watch, for ere the morning star
Sends out his glorious glister on the north,
The head will speak, then Miles upon thy life,
Wake me for then by Magic art I will work,
To end my seven years task with excellence,
If that a wink but shut thy watchful eye,
Then farewell Bacons glory and his fame,
Draw close the curtains Miles now for thy life,
Be watchful and

body.stage: Here he falleth asleepe.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p:
So, I thought you would talk yourself asleep anon, and it is no marvel, for Bungay on the days, and he on the nights, have watched Just these ten and fifty days, now this is the night, and it is my task and no more. Now Jesus bless me what a goodly head it is, and a nose, you talk of nos autem glortficare,
but here is a nose, that I warrant may be called nos autem popelare for the people of the parish, well I am furnished with weapons, now sir I will set me down by a post, and make it as good as a watchman to wake me if I chance to slumber. I thought goodman head, I would call you out of your memento,

body.stage: Sit down and knocke your head

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: passions-a-God I have almost broke my pate, Up Miles to your task, take your browne bill in your hand, here is some of your masters hobgoblins abroad.

body.stage: With this a great noise. The Head speakes.

sp.speaker: Head.
sp.p: Time is.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p:
Time is, Why master Brazen head have you such a
