capital nose, and answer you with syllables, Time is: is this all my masters cunning, to spend seven years study about Time is: well sir, it may be we shall have some better orations of it anon, well I will watch you as narrowly as ever you were watched, and I will play with you as the Nightingale with the Slowworm, I will set a prick against my breast: now rest there Miles, Lord have mercy upon me, I have almost killed myself: up Miles list how they rumble.

sp.speaker: Head.
sp.p: Time was.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Well friar Bacon, you spent your seven years study well that can make your Head speak but two words at once, Time was: yea marie, time was when my master was a wise man, but that was before he began to make the Brazen head, you shall lie while your arse ache and your Head speak no better: well I will watch and walk up and down, and be a Perepatetian and a Philosopher of Aristotles stamp, what a fresh noise, take thy pistols in hand Miles.

body.stage: Heere the Head speakes and a lightning flasheth forth, and a hand appeares that breaketh down the Head with a hammer.

sp.speaker: Head.
sp.p: Time is past.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Master master, up hell is broken loose, your Head speaks, and there is such a thunder and lightning, that I warrant all Oxford is up in arms, out of your bed and take a browne bill in your hand, the latter day is come.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Miles I come, o passing warily watched,
Bacon will make thee next himself in love,
When spake the Head?

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p:
When spake the Head, did not you say that he
should tell strange principles of Philosophy, why sir it speaks but two words at a time.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Why villain hath it spoken oft.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Oft, aye marie hath it thrice: but in all those three times it hath uttered but seven words.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: As how

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p:
Marry sir, the first time he said, Time is, as if Fabius cumentator should have pronounced a sentence, he said Time was,
and the third time with thunder and lightning, as in great choler, he said Time is past.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: It is past indeed, a villain time is past,
My life, my fame, my glory, all are past:
Bacon, the turrets of thy hope are ruined down,
Thy seven years study lieth in the dust:
Thy Brazen head lies broken through a slave
That watched, and would not when the Head did will,
What said the Head first.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Even sir, Time is,

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Villain if thou hadst called to Bacon then,
If thou hadst watched and waked the sleepy friar,
The Brazen head had uttered Aphorisms,
And England had been circled round with brass,
But proud Asteroth ruler of the North,
And Demigorgon master of the fates,
Grudge that a mortal man should work so much,
Hell trembled at my deep commanding spells,
Fiends frowned to see a man their overmatch,
Bacon might boast more than a man might boast:
But now the braves of Bacon hath an end,
Europes conceit of Bacon hath an end:
His seven years practise sorteth to ill end:
And villain sith my glory hath an end
I will appoint thee fatal to some end,
Villain avoid, get thee from Bacons sight:
Vagrant go rome and range about the world,
And perish as a vagabond on earth.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Why then sir you forbid me your service.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: My service villain with a fatal curse,
That direful plagues and mischief fall on thee.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: It is no matter I am against you with the old proverb, The more the fox is cursed the better he fares: God be with you sir, I will take but a book in my hand, a wide sleeved gown on my back, and a crowned cap on my head, and see if I can want promotion.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Some fiend or ghost haunt on thy weary steps,
Until they do transport thee quick to hell,
For Bacon shall have never merry day,
To lose the fame and honour of his Head.

stage.emph:
Exit.
Enter Emperour, Castile, Ellinor, Edward, Lacie, Raphe.

sp.speaker: Emper.
sp.l: Now lovely Prince the prince of Albions wealth,
How fares the lady Ellinor and you:
What have you courted and found Castile sir,
To answer England in equivalence
Will it be a match twixt bonny Nell and thee.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Should Paris enter in the courts of Greece,
And not lie fettered in fair Hellens looks,
Or Phoebus scape those piercing amorets,
That Daphne glanced at his deity:
Can Edward then sit by a flame and freeze,
Whose heat puts Hellen and fair Daphne down,
Now Monarchs ask the lady if we agree.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: What madam hath my son found grace or no.

sp.speaker: Ellinor.
sp.l: Seeing my lord his lovely counterfeit,
And hearing how his mind and shape agreed,
I come not trooped with all this warlike train,
Doubting of love, but so affectionate
As Edward hath in England what he won in Spain.

sp.speaker: Castile.
sp.l: A match my lord, these wantons needs must love,
Men must have wives and women will be wed,
Let us haste the day to honour up the rites.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: sirrah Harry, shall Ned marry Nell.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Aye Raphe, how then.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: Marry Harry follow my counsel, send for friar Bacon to marry them, for he will so conjure him and her with his Nigromancy, that they shall love together like pig and lamb whilst they live.

sp.speaker: Castile.
sp.p: But hearst thou Raphe, art thou content to have Ellinor to thy lady.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.l: Aye so she will promise me two things.

sp.speaker: Castile.
sp.p: What is that Raphe.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: That she will never scold with Ned nor fight with me, sirrah Harry I have put her down with a thing unpossible.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: What is that Raphe.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: Why Harry didst thou ever see that a woman could both hold her tongue and her hands, no but when egg-pies grows on apple trees, then will thy gray mare prove a bagpiper

sp.speaker: Emperor.
sp.p: What says the lord of Castile and the earl of Lincoln, that they are in such earnest and secret talk.

sp.speaker: Castile.
sp.l: I stand my lord amazed at his talk
How he discourseth of the constancy,
Of some surnamed for beauties excellence,
The fair maid of merry Fresingfield.

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.l: It is true my lord, it is wondrous for to hear,
Her beauty passing Marces paramour:
Her virgins right as rich as Vestas was,
Lacie and Ned hath told me miracles.

sp.speaker: Castile.
sp.l: What says lord Lacie, shall she be his wife,

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Or else lord Lacie is unfit to live,
May it please your highness give me leave to post
To Fresingfield I will fetch the bonny girl,
And prove in true appearance at the court
What I have vouched often with my tongue.

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.l: Lacie, go to the quire of my stable,
And take such coursers as shall fit thy turn,
Hie thee to Fresingfield and bring home the lass,
And for her fame flies through the English coast,
If it may please the lady Ellinor,
One day shall match your excellence and her.

sp.speaker: Ellinor.
sp.l: We Castile ladies are not very coy,
Your highness may command a greater boon,
And glad were I to grace the Lincoln earl
With being partner of his marriage day.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Gramercy Nell for I do love the lord,
As he that is second to myself in love.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p: You love her, madam Nell, never believe him you though he swears he loves you.

sp.speaker: Ellinor
sp.p: Why Raphe.

sp.speaker: Raphe.
sp.p:
Why his love is like unto a tapsters glass that is broken with every truth, for he loved the fair maid of Fresingfield
one out of all ho, nay Ned never wink upon me, I care not I.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Raphe tells all, you shall have a good secretary of him,
But Lacie haste thee post to Fresingfield:
For ere thou hast fitted all things for her state,
The solemn marriage day will be at hand.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: I go my lord.

body.stage: Exit Lacie.

sp.speaker: Emperor.
sp.l: How shall we pass this day my lord.

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.l: To horse my lord, the day is passing fair,
We will fly the partridge or go rouse the deer,
Follow my lords, you shall not want for sport.

body.stage: Exeunt.
Enter frier Bacon with frier Bungay to his cell.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: What means the friar that frolicked it of late,
To sit as melancholy in his cell:
To sit as melancholy in his cell,
As if he had neither lost nor won today.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Ah Bungay my Brazen head is spoiled,
My glory gone, my seven years study lost:
The fame of Bacon bruited through the world,
Shall end and perish with this deep disgrace.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: Bacon hath built foundation on his fame,
So surely on the wings of true report,
With acting strange and uncouth miracles,
As this cannot infringe what he deserves.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Bungay sit down, for by prospective skill,
I find this day shall fall out ominous,
Some deadly act shall tide me ere I sleep:
But what and wherein little can I guess.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: My mind is heavy whatsoever shall hap.

body.stage: Enter two schollers, sonnes to Lambert and Serlby. Knocke.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Who is that knocks.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: Two scholars that desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Bid them come in, Now my youths what would you have.

sp.speaker: 1. Sholler.
sp.l: Sir we are Suffolke men and neighbouring friends,
Our fathers in their countries lusty squires,
Their lands adjoin, in Crackfield mine doth dwell,
And his in Laxfield, we are college mates,
Sworn brothers as our fathers lives as friends.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: To what end is all this.

sp.speaker: 2. Scholar.
sp.l: Hearing your worship kept within your cell
A glass prospective wherein men might see,
Whatso their thoughts or hearts desire could wish,
We come to know how that our fathers fare.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: My glass is free for every honest man,
Sit down and you shall see ere long,
How or in what state your friendly father lives,
Mean while tell me your names.

sp.speaker: Lambert.
sp.l: Mine Lambert.

sp.speaker: 2. Scholar.
sp.l: And mine Serlsbie.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Bungay, I smell there will be a tragedy.

body.stage: Enter Lambert and Serlsbie, with Rapiers and daggers.

sp.speaker: Lambert.
sp.l: Serlsby thou hast kept thine hour like a man,
Thou art worthy of the title of squire:
That durst for proof of thy affection,
And for thy mistress favour prize thy blood,
Thou knowest what words did pass at Fresingfield,
Such shameless braves as manhood cannot brooke:
Aye for I scorn to bear such piercing taunts,
Prepare thee Serlsbie one of us will die.

sp.speaker: Serlsbie.
sp.l: Thou seest I single thee the field,
And what I spake, I will maintain with my sword.
Stand on thy guard I cannot scold it out.
And if thou kill me, think I have a son,
That lives in Oxford in the Brodgates hall,
Who will revenge his fathers blood with blood.

sp.speaker: Lambert.
sp.l: And Serlsbie I have there a lusty boy,
That dares at weapon buckle with thy son,
And lives in Broadgates too as well as thine,
But draw thy Rapier for we will have a bout.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Now lusty younkers look within the glass,
And tell me if you can discern your sires.

sp.speaker: 1. Scol.
sp.l: Serlsbie it is hard, thy father offers wrong,
To combat with my father in the field.

sp.speaker: 2. Schol.
sp.l: Lambert thou liest, my fathers is the abuse,
And thou shalt find it, if my father harm.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: How goes it sirs.

sp.speaker: 1. Scholar.
sp.l: Our fathers are in combat hard by Fresingfield.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Sit still my friends and see the event.

sp.speaker: Lambert.
sp.l: Why standest thou Serlsbie doubtest thou of thy life,
A very man, fair Margret craves so much.

sp.speaker: Serlbie.
sp.l: Then this for her.

sp.speaker: 1. Scholar.
sp.l: Ah well thrust.

sp.speaker: 2. Scholar.
sp.l: But mark the ward.

body.stage: They fight and kill ech other.

sp.speaker: Lambert.
sp.l: O I am slain.

sp.speaker: Serlbie.
sp.l: And I, Lord have mercy on me.

sp.speaker: 1. Scholar.
sp.l: My father is slain, Serlby ward that.

body.stage: The two schollers stab on another.

sp.speaker: 2. Scholar.
sp.l: And so is mine Lambert, I will quite thee well.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: O strange stratagem.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: See Friar where the fathers both lie dead.
Bacon thy magic doth effect this massacre:
This glass prospective worketh many woes,
And therefore seeing these brave lusty brutes,
These friendly youths did perish by thine art,
End all thy magic and thine art at once:
The poniard that did end the fatal lives,
Shall break the cause efficiat of their woes,
So fade the glass, and end with it the shows,
That Nigromancy did ensue the crystal with.

body.stage: He breakes the glasse.

sp.speaker: Bungay.
sp.l: What means learned Bacon thus to break his glass.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: I tell thee Bungay it repents me sore,
That ever Bacon meddled in this art,
The hours I have spent in pyromantic spells,
The fearful tossing in the latest night,
Of papers full of nigromantic charms,
Conjuring and abjuring devils and fiends,
With stole and albe and strange Pentaganon,
The wresting of the holy name of God,
As Sother, Elaim, and Adonaie,
Apha, Minoth, and Tetragamiton,
With praying to the five-fold powers of heaven,
Are instances that Bacon must be damned,
For using devils to countervail his God.
Yet Bacon cheer thee, drown not in despair,
Sins have their salves repentance can do much,
Think mercy sits where Justice hold her seat,
And from those wounds those bloody Jews did pierce
Which by thy magic oft did bleed afresh,
From thence for thee the dew of mercy drops,
To wash the wrath of hie Iehouahs ire,
And make thee as a new born babe from sin,
Bungay I will spend the remnant of my life
In pure devotion praying to my God,
That he would save what Bacon vainly lost.

body.stage:
Exit.
Enter Margret in Nuns apparrell, Keeper, her father, and their friend.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Margret be not so headstrong in these vows,
O bury not such beauty in a cell:
That England hath held famous for the hue,
Thy fathers hair like to the silver blooms:
That beautify the shrubs of Africa
Shall fall before the dated time of death,
Thus to forgo his lovely Margret.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Ah father when the harmony of heaven,
founded the measures of a lively faith:
The vain Illusions of this flattering world,
Seems odious to the thoughts of Margret,
I loved once, lord Lacie was my love,
And now I hate myself for that I loved,
And doted more on him than on my God:
For this I scourge myself with sharp repents,
But now the touch of such aspiring sins
Tells me all love is lust but love of heavens:
That beauty used for love is vanity,
The world contains naught but alluring baits:
Pride, flattery, and inconstant thoughts,
To shun the pricks of death I leave the world,
And vow to meditate on heavenly bliss,
To live in Framingham a holy Nun,
Holy and pure in conscience and in deed:
And for to wish all maids to learn of me,
To seek heavens joy before earths vanity.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And will you then Margret be shorn a Nun, and so leave us all.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Now farewell world the engine of all woe,
Farewell to friends and fathers, welcome Christ:
Adieu to dainty robes, this base attire
Better befits an humble mind to God,
Than all the show of rich habiliments,
Love, o Love, and with fond Love farewell,
Sweet Lacie whom I loved once so dear,
Ever be well, but never in my thoughts,
Lest I offend to think on Lacies love:
But even to that as to the rest farewell.

body.stage: Enter Lacie, Warrain, Ermsbie, booted and spurd.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Come on my wags we are near the keepers lodge,
Here have I oft walked in the watery Meads,
And chatted with my lovely Margret.

sp.speaker: Warraine.
sp.p: sirrah Ned, is not this the keeper.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.p: It is the same.

sp.speaker: Ermsbie.
sp.p: The old lecher hath gotten holy mutton to him a Nun my lord.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Keeper how farest thou holla man, what cheer,
How doth Peggie thy daughter and my love.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: Ah good my lord, o woe is me for Pegge,
See where she stands clad in her Nuns attire,
Ready for to be shorn in Framingham:
She leaves the world because she left your love,
O good my lord persuade her if you can.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Why how now Margret, what a malcontent,
A Nun, what holy father taught you this
To task yourself to such a tedious life,
As die a maid, it were injury to me.
To smother up such beauty in a cell.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Lord Lacie thinking of thy former miss,
How fond the prime of wanton years were spent
In love, O fie upon that fond conceit,
Whose hap and essence hangeth in the eye,
I leave both love and loves content at once,
Betaking me to him that is true love,
And leaving all the world for love of him.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Whence Peggie comes this Metamorphosis.
What shorn a Nun, and I have from the court,
Posted with coursers to convey thee hence,
To Windsore, where our Marriage shall be kept,
Thy wedding robes are in the tailors hands,
Come Peggy leave these peremptory vows.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Did not my lord resign his interest,
And make divorce twixt Margret and him?

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: It was but to try sweet Peggies constancy,
But will fair Margret leave her love and Lord?

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Is not heavens joy before earths fading bliss,
And life above sweeter than life in love,

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Why then Margret will be shorn a Nun,

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Margret hath made a vow which may not be revoked.

sp.speaker: Warraine.
sp.l: We cannot stay my Lord, and if she be so strict,
Our leisure grants us not to woo afresh.

sp.speaker: Ermsby.
sp.l: Choose your fair damsel, yet the choice is yours,
Either a solemn Nunnery, or the court,
God, or Lord Lacie, which; contents you best,
To be a Nun, or else Lord Lacies wife.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: A good motion, Peggie your answer must be short.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: The flesh is frail, my Lord doth know it well,
That when he comes with his enchanting face,
Whatsoever betide I cannot say him nay,
Off goes the habit of maidens heart,
And seeing Fortune will, fair Fremingham,
And all the show of holy Nuns farewell,
Lacie for me, if he will my lord.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: Peggie thy Lord, thy love, thy husband,
Trust me, by truth of knighthood, that the King
Stays for to marry matchless Ellinour,
Until I bring thee richly to the court,
That one day may both marry her and thee,
How sayst thou Keeper art thou glad of this?

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: As if the English King had given
The park and deer of Frisingfield to me.

sp.speaker: Erms.
sp.p: I pray thee my Lord of Sussex why art thou in a brown study?

sp.speaker: Warraine.
sp.p: To see the nature of women, that be they never so near God, yet they love to die in a man's arms.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.p: What have you fit for breakfast? we have hied and posted all this night to Frisingfield.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: Butter and cheese and humbles of a Deer,
Such as poor Keepers have within their lodge.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.l: And not a bottle of wine?

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: We will find one for my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lacie.
sp.p: Come Sussex let us in, we shall have more, for she speaks least, to hold her promise sure.

body.stage: Exeunt. Enter a deuill to seeke Miles.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: How restless are the ghosts of hellish spirits,
When every charmer with his Magic spells
Calls us from nine-fold trenched Blegiton,
To scud and overscour the earth in post,
Upon the speedy wings of swiftest winds,
Now Bacon hath raised me from the darkest deep,
To search about the world for Miles his man,
For Miles, and to torment his lazy bones,
For careless watching of his Brazen head,
See where he comes, O he is mine.

body.stage: Enter Miles with a gowne and a corner cap.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: A scholar quoth you, marry sir I would I had been made a bottle-maker when I was made a scholar, for I can get neither to be a Deacon, Reader, nor Schoolmaster, no, not the clarke of a parish, some call me dunce, another saith my head is as full of Latin as an egg is full of oatmeal, thus I am tormented that the devil and Friar Bacon, haunts me, good Lord here is one of my masters devils, I will go speak to him, what master Plutus, how cheer you?

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: Dost thou know me?

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p:
Know you sir, why are not you one of my masters devils, that were wont to come to my master Doctor Bacon, at
Brazen nose?
Yes marry am I.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p:
Good Lord Master. Plutus I have seen you a thousand
times at my masters and yet I had never the manners to make you drink, but sir, I am glad to see how conformable you are to the statute, I warrant you he is as yeomanly a man, as you shall see, mark you masters, here is a plain honest man, without welt or guard, but I pray you sir do you come lately from hell?

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: Aye marry how then,

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Faith it is a place I have desired long to see, have you not good tippling houses there, may not a man have a lusty fire there, a pot of good ail, a pair of cards, a swinging piece of chalk, and a browne toast that will clap a white waistcoat on a cup of good drink?

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: All this you may have there.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: You are for me friend, and I am for you, but I pray you, may I not have an office there?

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: Yes a thousand, what wouldst thou be?

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: By my troth sir in a place where I may profit myself, I know hell is a hot place, and men are marvelous dry, and much drink is spent there, I would be a tapster.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: Thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: There is nothing lets me from going with you, but that it is a long journey, and I have never a horse.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: Thou shalt ride on my back.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Now surely here is a courteous devil, that for to pleasure his friend will not stick to make a jade of himself, but I pray you goodman friend let me move a question to you.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: I pray you whether is your pace a trot or an amble?

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: An amble.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.l: It is well, but take heed it be not a trot,
But it is no matter I will prevent it.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: What dost?

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: Marry friend I put on my spurs, for if I find your pace either a trot or else uneasy, I will put you to a false gallop, I will make you feel the benefit of my spurs.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: Get up upon my back.

sp.speaker: Miles.
sp.p: O Lord here is even a goodly marvel, when a man rides to hell on the Devils back.

body.stage: Exeunt roring. Enter the Emperour with a pointles sword, next the King of Castile, carrying a sword with a point, Lacie carying the globe Ed. Warr. carrying a rod of god with a doue on it, Ermsby with a and Scepter, The queene with the faire maide of Frisingfield on her left hand, Henry, Bacon with other Lords attending.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Great potentates earths miracles for state,
Think that prince Edward humbles at your feet,
And for these favours on his marital sword,
He vows perpetual homage to yourselves,
Yielding these honours unto Ellinour.

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.l: Gramercy Lordlings, old Plantagenet,
That rules and sways the Albion diadem,
With tears discovers these conceived joys,
And vows requital, if his men-at-arms,
The wealth of England, or due honours done
To Ellinour, may quite his favourites,
But all this while what say you to the Dames,
That shine like to the crystal lamps of heaven?

sp.speaker: Emperor.
sp.l: If but a third were added to these two
They did surpass those gorgeous images,
That gloried Ida with rich beauties wealth.

sp.speaker: Margret.
sp.l: It is I my lords who humbly on my knee,
Must yield her orisons to mighty Jove,
For lifting up his handmaid to this state,
Brought from her homely cottage to the court,
And graced with Kings Princes and Emperors,
To whom (next to the noble Lincoln Earl)
I vow obedience, and such humble love,
As may a handmaid to such mighty men.

sp.speaker: Ellinour.
sp.l: Thou martial man that wears the Almain crown,
And you the western Potentates of might,
The Albian Princess, English Edwards wife,
Proud that the lovely star of Frisingfield,
Fair Margret, Countess to the Lincoln Earl,
Attends on Ellinour, gramercy Lord for her,
It is I give thanks for Margret to you all,
And rest for her due bounden to your selves.

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.l: Seeing the marriage is solemnised,
Let us march in triumph to the royal feast,
But why stands Friar Bacon here so mute?

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: Repentant for the follies of my youth,
That Magics secret mysteries misled,
And joyful that this royal marriage,
Portends such bliss unto this matchless realm.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Why Bacon what strange event shall happen to this land
Or what shall grow from Edward and his Queen.

sp.speaker: Bacon.
sp.l: I find by deep prescience of mine art,
Which once I tempered in my secret cell,
That here where Brute did build his Troymouant,
From forth the royal garden of a King,
Shall flourish out, so rich and fair a bud,
Whose brightness shall deface proud Phoebus flower,
And overshadow Albion with her leaves.
Till then, Mars shall be master of the field,
But then the stormy threats of wars shall cease,
The horse shall stamp as careless of the pike,
Drums shall be turned to timbrels of delight,
With wealthy favours, plenty shall enrich,
The strand that gladded wandering Brute to see,
And peace from heaven shall harbour in these leaves,
That gorgeous beautifies this matchless flower,
Appollos Hellitropian then shall stoop,
And Venus hyacinth shall vail her top,
Iuno shall shut her gillyflowers up,
And Palace bay shall bash her brightest green,
Ceres carnation in comfort with those,
Shall stoop and wonder at Dianas rose.

sp.speaker: Henrie.
sp.l: This Prophecy is mystical,
But glorious commanders of Europas love,
That makes fair England like that wealthy Isle,
Circled with Gihen, and first Euphrates,
In royalizing Henries Albion,
With presence of your princely mightiness,
Let us march, the tables all are spread,
And viands such as Englands wealth affords,
Are ready set to furnish out the boards,
You shall have welcome mighty potentates,
It rests to furnish up this royal feast,
Only your hearts be frolic for the time,
Craves that we taste of naught but jouisance,
Thus glories England over all the west.

body.stage: Exeunt omnes.
Finis Frier Bacon, made by Robert Greene, Master of Arts. Omne tulit punctum qui miscuit vtile dulci.
